ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed skills in critical reading and comparative literature analysis
Though this course did teach me a lot about how to improve my writing, it also taught close reading of texts, conducting library research, as well as class discussions and short presentations.
I learned how to approach intimidating texts, breaking them down into their literary components and picking out continuous themes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: There was a great amount of material covered and wonderful connections across time and space. however, the workload was difficult to get through at times.

This course is a Yale classic -- anyone interested in literature should consider taking the course. The reading list has been perfected over time and there is a strong macro-level narrative that connects the works you read. Further, Professor Barasch is super knowledgeable and passionate about the works being discussed. He truly is the highlight of the semester.

The texts themselves were interesting, the professor-led discussion was engaging, and I always looked forward to every class. However, because we only met twice a week and had so much reading, sometimes I felt like we weren't able to touch some of the content we read during the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, I really enjoyed this course though it was very difficult

I would recommend this course to a student that is prepared for a great amount of work in reading the difficult texts, preparing for class discussions, and writing close reading essays. This course is a condensed version of the DS sequence.
Yes, but only if they are willing to commit 10+ hours to reading each week.
I would, provided they have a keen interest in the coursework. Because of the high course load, if you were not interested, it would be very easy to fall behind and feel lost.

extras.title: ENGL 130 01/LITR 169 01 - Epic in European Lit Tradition
